content:
Alright, who’s seen this movie? It’s not exactly underground but it’s
came out, what 27 years ago now and I don’t
think it was a huge blockbuster at the time. But it’s always been a movie I really loved.

An average man, pushed to the breaking point
by the mundane frustrations of the world. But I gotta be real clear here, as I know
some people like take things the wrong way.

Bill, the main character in this film is a
horrible psychopath. He’s the bad guy.

This should be painfully obvious to anyone
watching the film, but there are moments in the move that the wrong kind of person with
the wrong ideology could look at as a glorification

of terrible views and actions. But with this diorama I am honouring the film,
not glorifying the character.

I’m making this as a tribute to a villain,
not a hero. I had actually been many years since watching
the movie when I built this.

I thought about watching it before starting,
but instead decided to go off of memory and the iconic cover scene alone.

Instead I watched the movie right after finishing
the piece as a bit of a celebration of accomplishment. I spent a fair bit of time trying to get the
little set of concrete steps right.

This was harder than I thought as they have
a weird design and it’s sort of hard to get a gauge on their bizarre layout from the
cover photo.

I was also eyeballing the scale without any
reference as the Bill model was quietly printing in the background while I built the base.

This diorama wouldn’t have a lot going on
aside from the Bill character and the steps so it was pretty important to get those steps
looking right, and throughout the course of

making the base I actually modified them over
and over and over again until I finally got them looking close to the cover scene photo.

It’s kind of funny because I first made
the steps with the hotwire cutter, but by the end of all the revisions I’m pretty
sure the finished steps were cut entirely

with a knife. I’ve struggled a fair bit in the past getting
this little bases looking good on the edges,

but this time around I didn’t run into any
major issues and I think I’m finally getting a good grasp on how to tackle this seemingly
mundane task that carries such importance

for the finished piece. In the time that it took me to assemble the
base, the Bill mini was able to print start

to finish on my resin printer. I’m sure some of you are wondering how I
managed to find such a perfect Bill model

to print. Well that was thanks to the sponsor of this
episode.

Colossal Miniatures provides high quality
3d printer friendly miniatures for rpgs, tabletop gamers, and collectors.

The make their models available through a
monthly patreon service that costs only $10 a month.

When you join up you will instantly get access
to a massive welcome pack containing 40 minis! After that you will get access to the monthly
release of themed miniatures.

What’s cool about this company is that their
service provides both classic fantasy rpg themed minis geared towards games like dungeons
and dragons, as well as things like their

modern survivors which is a running themed
set of modern characters based on classic movies.

These modern survivors are the reason I wanted
to work with this company. As soon as I saw they had a Bill model I knew
I had to have it and make something with it.

But at the same time I was torn because they
had all these other iconic characters that I also wanted to work with.

But in the end I could only pick one. If you were to sign up youd get access to
these really neat modern characters for movie

dioramas or modern tabletop games. But you’d also have a wealth of options
for your d&d campaign.

It’s the best of both worlds. They even have a loyalty program that gives
customers bonus zombified versions of these

models after they’ve been a member for 3
months. Now at the time of filming this video they
have a limited amount of pledge spots left

priced at only $9 a month. I expect that after this video those will
quickly vanish.

So if you want to get in on these cool models
I’d recommend signing up while you can get the trailblazer discount.

And hey, if you miss it, $10 a month is still
a crazy good deal for all the minis you get. Thanks colossal miniatures for sponsoring
this build, but more importantly thanks for
creating this awesome mini. What a time to be alive.

Because building the scenic bas didn’t take
very long I was able to go into painting the mini with a comfortable amount of time to
work.

I’ve been really guilty of rushing a lot
of paint jobs in the past. And I often find myself disinterested in the
painting portion of the hobby.

But over the past few months I’ve started
to increase my skill level and this made me cross a sort of threshold where my ability
allowed me to enjoy the process more, and

gave me the opportunity to actually develop
my techniques. I wanted to do a paintjob on Bill that I’d
be really really proud of.

So I took some time to really consider the
colour palette. His white shirt and black paints were pretty
limiting, but I used this as motivation to
try and do those materials really well. I even decided to avoid using washes entirely.

I wanted to force myself to use some precision,
and to work on better layering and blending techniques.

So I didn’t rush. I really took my time to calmly and methodically
build up the shadows and highlights on his

shirt, pants, and skin. I was even feeling relaxed and confident enough
to freehand on the strips on his tie, despite
my tremor. For me this was a huge victory.

I was also feeling confident enough to try
some simple non metallic metals on the gun and briefcase.

This is completely out of character for me
to not just reach for a bottle of metallic paints.

And I honestly couldn’t be happier with
my choice to try this method instead for once. I also carefully painted in several different
colours for his hair, trying to get somewhat

realistic highlights as well as some subtle
grey strands. I am really happy with what I managed to do
on him.

It was a lot of fun to spend time on different
materials like the worn leather on his briefcase. I did make one error in judgement though.
His glasses. Glasses on minis are tricky.

This model was designed without solid lenses,
which is pretty impressive that they printed like that.

I should have left them that way. But I had this idea to fill them with clear
resin to look like glass.

This was a total mistake, it looked bad, and
I ended up painting over the resin. Now his glasses were solid and looked more
like glasses.

My one regret. I should have left them as the model designers
intended.

Despite that one flub, I was overall happy
with how he was looking and it inspired me to continue refining the details.

All those comments from anonymous people on
the internet telling me that I’m a terrible painter washed away.
You know what? Those people are wrong.

I can paint well as long as I don’t get
lazy or get rushed, and reminding myself of that is important because it’s easy to feel
like you might as well rush something because
you think you are bad at it. So take the time.
Remind yourself that you can do this. You’ll be happier for it.

Small details make the diorama. This was mostly an empty scene but it had
a few key elements.

One is some bits of rebar sticking out from
the stairs. I used some push pins for the large rebar,
and a tiny bit of window screen for the smaller

stuff on the side. But the most important detail is the iconic
can of coke sitting on the steps.

I actually used a tiny bit of toothpick that
I embedded into the foam, with just enough protruding to create the cylinder can.

Rather than just painting the concrete out
grey and doing a quick dry brush and wash I played around blending some different warmer
tones to mimic the way the sun hit the steps

in the photo. And a crucial part of the base painting is
of course all that graffiti.

These steps in the movie are heavily covered
is spray painted tags and whatnot and I did my best to portray that with brush and paint.

A little red, white, and a touch of bright
silver finished off the can of coke. I needed a way to mimic the grass and dirt
so I turned to my supply of base ready mixes

from my buddy luke at geek gaming, and pulled
out some grass tufts and clump foliage from my collection.

I used a bit of very long reed type grass
to create the exact little tuft you see in the photo on the side of the steps and added
in a few grass tufts across the base.

In the photo there are some trees or bushes
in the distance. Now my base doesn’t extend that far, but
to capture that look I made one larger bush

on the back corner. This is such a fun part of the process and
it really brings things to life.

One of these days I will get around to getting
a static grass applicator. I think that would have made it just that
much better if I had used a proper applicator

rather than simply sprinkling on some static
grass. But all things considered the grass on this
piece still looks pretty darn nice.

The most exciting point in any diorama build
is placing the finished and painted model in the scene.

One slight problem, you may not be able to
see, but one of his feet has the toe of the shoe broken off.

This must have broken when I removed the supports
and I didn’t notice until midway through painting it.

To hide this I came up with the simple solution
of having a tiny piece of garbage paper blowing onto his foot.

This doesn’t just cover the problem, it’s
actually really on theme for the build. In the movie, the reason bill sits down on
those steps is to fix a hole in the bottom

of his shoe with a bit of folded up newspaper. So fixing the models broken shoe with a bit
of paper has a bit of poetic beauty to it.

Or at least I think so. This inspired me to add a bit more little
bits of garbage using tiny bits of paper,

foil and plastic. I think this might be my favourite diorama
I’ve made yet.

It’s definitely the miniature I’m the
most proud of painting. It felt really good to paint him too, it was
a liberating experience in a way to finally

do a mini using a little more advanced techniques
than a wash and highlight. What do you guys think?

I hope you enjoyed the video. If you did hit the like button and let me
know in the comments section.

Maybe this will inspire you to do you own
little diorama of an old favourite, and often forgotten movie.

If you want to grab some hobby supplies for
yourself and support the channel in the process be sure to check out blackmagiccraft.ca, there
I have an essential equipment page where I

explain the stuff I use most often and buying
through that page helps fund the production of videos like this.

If you want to help out in an even bigger
way, you can do so buy joining the black magic craft fellowship on patreon.

Joining there get’s you into the private
facebook group, discord, and lets you see videos a little early.

And that support is the main reason I am able
to make weekly hobby videos. Thanks for watching.
And remember folks. Bill is the bad guy.
